CONDITION DESCRIPTION: Anxiety & other neurotic, stress related & somatoform disorders
USAGE DEFINITION: Read code in last 12 months OR = 4 anxiolytic/hypnotic prescriptions in last 12 months
PROVENANCE:
List was created using chapter 4.1.1 (Hypnotics and Anxiolytics) in the BNF, but it excluded melatonin, promethazine, oxybate, chloral hydrate, chlorodiazepoxide.  It also included the anxiolytics in chapter 4.1.2 and trazadone.

Anxiety medication lists are hard to create, because many such drugs have multiple indications.  We did not include SSRIs or tricyclics, which are probably the most commonly used drugs for anxiety, but have many other indications.  Therefore patients are only captured within this variable if they have an appropriate Read code or a LIMITED list of anxiety meds.  However, SSRIs would be included in a broadened "depression or anxiety" multimorbidity variable, which is what we recommend unless you are specificially interested in depression or anxiety.

Use a combination of anxiety and/or depression as one disease/illness grouping, both defined by read code or drugs.used to treat depression, and a mixture of anxiety and depression is common.  Therefore our group's consensus is to use a combination.

CONDITION DESCRIPTION: Anxiety & other neurotic, stress related & somatoform disorders
USAGE DEFINITION: Read code in last 12 months OR = 4 anxiolytic/hypnotic prescriptions in last 12 months
PROVENANCE: This is a large and broad list of anxiety codes developed from the Scottish ISD list by Dr Duncan Edwards that has never been double checked or re-assessed, rather we have been focussing on the drug lists and how anxiety interacts with depression. Unless it's a mental health project, I'd advise overlapping anxiety and/or depression as one disease/illness category to avoid double counting patients and because many drugs and some Read codes overlap both conditions. We should consider further review of the Read code list, e.g. should terms like "tension headache" be included - I suspect not?  Other published lists exist and further investigation of these will occur to develop a version 2 definition of anxiety.
